parts.text: State two environmental issues caused by generating electricity using nuclear power stations.
markScheme: 1 mark: Any valid issue, e.g. **radioactive** waste / waste has a long **half-life** / risk of catastrophic **accidents**
1 mark: Any second valid issue, e.g. fuel is **non-renewable** / waste is **toxic** / waste needs to be **buried**

parts.text: Explain briefly the difference between nuclear fission and nuclear fusion.
markScheme: 1 mark: Nuclear **fission** is the splitting of a large atomic **nucleus**
1 mark: Nuclear **fusion** is the joining of two atomic **nuclei** to form a larger one

parts.text: What is released during both nuclear fission and nuclear fusion?
markScheme: Answer: B - Both fission and fusion release energy

parts.text: Radioactive waste from nuclear power stations has a long half-life. Suggest one precaution taken to reduce the hazard caused by radioactive waste.
markScheme: 1 mark: Any valid precaution, e.g. **bury** the waste / store in **concrete** / transport in secure vessels / put in cooling ponds

parts.text: A nuclear power station generated electricity for 92% of a year. One year = 365 days. Calculate the number of days it generated electricity.
Although nuclear fuels are relatively cheap, the total cost of generating electricity using nuclear fuels is expensive. Why?
markScheme: 1 mark: Cost of **building** and **decommissioning** is very high (or cost of reprocessing/storage of nuclear waste)

parts.text: Explain what is meant by nuclear fission.
markScheme: 1 mark: A large **nucleus** is hit by a **neutron**
1 mark: It **splits** into smaller nuclei (and neutrons and energy are released)

parts.text: How does nuclear fission lead to a chain reaction?
markScheme: 1 mark: Additional **neutrons** released collide with other nuclei causing **further fission**

parts.text: The UK currently generates a lot of electricity by burning natural gas. This process releases carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. Figure 1 shows how the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has changed over the past 115 years. Figure 2 shows how the global temperature has changed over the past 115 years. Give one similarity and one difference between the data in Figure 1 and Figure 2.
markScheme: 1 mark: Similarity: both carbon dioxide concentration and global temperature have **increased** over the 115-year period (or both show a positive correlation)
1 mark: Difference: the carbon dioxide concentration continues to **increase** steadily whereas the temperature increase **levels off** (or CO$_2$ increases more quickly than temperature)

parts.text: Uranium-234 decays to thorium-230. Both transitions show a loss of 2 protons and 2 neutrons. How does this show that uranium-234 and thorium-230 emit alpha particles?
markScheme: 1 mark: Both lose **2 protons** and **2 neutrons** (which is the composition of an alpha particle)

parts.text: What makes uranium and thorium different elements?
acceptedAnswers: they have different numbers of protons
markScheme: 1 mark: Different number of **protons** in the nucleus (or different atomic number)

parts.text: Explain why the emission of gamma radiation does not cause a new element to be formed.
markScheme: 1 mark: Gamma involves no change in the number of **protons** in the nucleus (or gamma is a wave, not a particle)

parts.text: There are many isotopes of plutonium. What do the nuclei of different plutonium isotopes have in common?
acceptedAnswers: they have the same number of protons
markScheme: 1 mark: Same number of **protons** (or same atomic number)

parts.text: Rutherford and Marsden aimed a beam of alpha particles at a thin sheet of gold. Explain how the results of this experiment led to a new model of the atom.
markScheme: 1 mark: Most alpha particles passed **straight through** (suggesting atom is mostly **empty space**)
1 mark: A few particles were **deflected** through large angles
1 mark: Suggesting a concentrated, small **nucleus** that is **positively** charged (repelling positive alpha particles)

parts.text: Calder Hall nuclear power station is next to the Sellafield reprocessing plant. Suggest an advantage of having the two plants close together.
markScheme: 1 mark: Reduces risk of radioactive **leak** during transport (or cheaper transport)

parts.text: Iodine-138 has a half-life of 6 seconds. A sample contains 2000 atoms of iodine-138. How long will it take for the number of atoms to decrease to 125?

Figure 1 shows a nuclear equation representing the fission of uranium-235 (U-235). The equation shows U-235 being hit by a neutron, forming barium (Ba) and krypton (Kr), and releasing further neutrons. Use the information in the equation to describe the process of nuclear fission.
markScheme: 1 mark: A **neutron** is absorbed by the uranium-235 **nucleus**
1 mark: The nucleus **splits** into two smaller nuclei (barium and krypton)

parts.text: Explain why nuclear fusion reactors are not currently used to produce energy in power stations, even though scientists continue trying to develop them.
markScheme: 1 mark: Currently only **experimental** / the reaction does not last long enough / they use more **energy** than they produce
1 mark: But would provide another source of energy / **unlimited** fuel / would not produce **radioactive waste**

parts.text: At the very high temperatures in the Sun, hydrogen is converted into helium. It takes four hydrogen nuclei to produce one helium nucleus. The mass of one hydrogen nucleus is 1.007825 u and the mass of one helium nucleus is 4.002602 u. Calculate the loss in mass when four hydrogen nuclei produce one helium nucleus. Give your answer in atomic mass units (u).
Use your answer to the calculation above to explain how the Sun has been able to radiate huge amounts of energy for billions of years.
markScheme: 1 mark: The loss of **mass** results in the release of **energy** (via $E = mc^2$)
1 mark: Even a **small** loss of mass produces a **huge** amount of energy
